body:
There was indeed a change in behavior between Windows PowerShell and PowerShell (Core), in support of cross-platform consistency, so I don't think it's a regression (though I cannot speak to what extent there was awareness that the behaviors diverged as a result).

The PowerShell (Core)-internal change between 7.0.5 and 7.1 is owed to a change in .NET itself outside PowerShell's control (presumably, just moving to a new .NET version did it - I have no information on what prompted the change in .NET).

```powershell
# Reports "! . _" in 7.0.5 vs. "_ ! ." in 7.1 and later on a US-English machine.
[string[]] $a = '!', '_', '.'; [Array]::Sort($a, [StringComparer]::CurrentCultureIgnoreCase); $a -join ' '
```

However, even 7.05 didn't sort the same as `cmd.exe` with respect to non-ASCII characters:

It is also important to note that there is _no_ consistent behavior across the other shells and GUI file managers such as File Explorer.

The summary is:

* Each platform individually exhibits different behaviors in the (native-shell) terminal vs. in the GUI file manager (notably, natural sorting of trailing numbers).

* Different Unix-like platforms behave differently (macOS vs. Linux).

* Windows PowerShell exhibits different behavior with `Get-ChildItem` (ordinal sorting (by code-point value), as reported by the .NET file-enumeration APIs) vs. with tab-completion (lexical) - an unfortunate inconsistency.

* PowerShell (Core) now uses lexical sorting consistently, on all platforms, which means case-insensitive, current-culture-sensitive sorting; on Unix-like platforms it _must_ do its own sorting, because the underlying system APIs enumerate files unsorted.

---

I see the following options:

* (a) Leave everything as is, which has two benefits:
  * Simple implementation.
  * Consistent behavior across all platforms - even if it doesn't match any platform's native sorting.

* (b) Try to emulate the native shells _platform-specifically_, which would mean: 
  * Increased implementation complexity.
  * Ordinal sorting on Windows and macOS.
  * _Modified_ lexical sorting on Linux (emulating the specifics may be tricky, unless it is provided by a system call)

* (c) Stick with consistent cross-platform behavior, but switch to the "majority" sorting, which would be ordinal, because 2 out of 3 platforms - Windows and macOS - use it, but in terms of actual PowerShell usage Linux is probably the more important platform.

From a PowerShell (Core) perspective (alone), (b) and (c) would be breaking changes, given that a change wouldn't just affect the interactive experience (tab-completion) but also the order in which files are listed with `Get-Item` / `Get-ChildItem`.

---

For anyone who wants to experiment with the sort orders, here's test code:

<details>
```powershell
& {
  Push-Location ($td = New-Item -Force -ItemType Directory (Join-Path ([io.path]::GetTempPath()) $PID))

  $names = 'foo', 'foo_bar.cmd', 'foo_bar_cmd', 'foo_bar!cmd', 'f√∂o', 'foo10', 'foo2'

  $null = New-Item -Force $names

  '-- Ordinal sort'
  [Array]::Sort($names, [StringComparer]::OrdinalIgnoreCase); $names

  '-- Lexical sort (current culture)'
  [Array]::Sort($names, [StringComparer]::CurrentCultureIgnoreCase); $names

  '-- Tab-completion'
  (TabExpansion2 -inputScript 'Get-Item ' -cursorColumn 9).CompletionMatches.CompletionText

  '-- Get-ChildItem' # also applies to -Path and -Filter wildcards
  (Get-ChildItem).Name

  if ($env:OS -eq 'Windows_NT') {
    "-- cmd /c dir (Windows)"
    cmd /c dir /b

  } else {
    "-- ls ($(uname))"
    ls -1
  }

  Invoke-Item . # Show the folder in the platform's GUI file manager.

  Read-Host '-- GUI File Manager launched; press Enter to clean up and exit; to test tab-completion in the native shell, press Ctrl-C now, and enter a native shell; rerun the script without aborting later to clean up'

  Pop-Location; Remove-Item $td -Recurse
}
```
</details>
Any movement here?  I don't see why, in any universe, '_' should come before '.' for file listing or tab-completion...

@jessey-git
It's at least consistent with the output of get-childitem.

@ckruegerkpmg Not really. Get-ChildItem always used to match.

```
-a---           11/5/2021 11:30 PM      286814208 blender.pdb
```

Why is `_` sorted first before `-` or `.`?  It is possible to be consistent across the platforms without this stupid sort order (and match much more closely everyone else).  The proper order should be "-", ".", and then "_" minimally.
